importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Paris Climate Agreement was adopted in 2015, marking a pivotal shift in global climate policy and serving as a baseline for comparing future warming scenarios.
The study projects future warming trends from current emissions commitments, with the 2.6°C warming scenario based on actions taken since the Paris Agreement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects how superhot days will accumulate annually up to 2100 under current emission pathways, emphasizing long-term climate risks.

keyTakeAways: Climate change is adding approximately 57 superhot days per year by 2100, defined as days warmer than 90% of comparable days from 1991–2020.
The Paris Climate Agreement reduced the projected warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, cutting the number of superhot days from 114 to 57 annually.
Since 2015, the planet has already seen 11 extra superhot days on average.
Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will face disproportionately large increases in superhot days, with Panama expected to gain 149 extra days annually.
The top carbon-emitting countries (U.S., China, India) are responsible for 42% of global CO2 emissions but face only 23–30 additional superhot days.
These disparities highlight a significant climate injustice, with low-emitting, vulnerable nations bearing the brunt of extreme heat.
Experts warn that such heat inequality could exacerbate geopolitical instability and deepen global inequities.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This entity conducted the core study estimating the rise in superhot days due to climate change, providing scientific credibility to the findings.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agreement is central to the study’s comparison between pre- and post-Paris warming trajectories, illustrating its impact on future climate risks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new climate study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central projects that, even under current emission commitments, the world will experience 57 additional superhot days annually by 2100—nearly two months of extreme heat—due to climate change. This represents a significant reduction from the 114 superhot days projected under a pre-Paris warming trajectory of 4°C. Since 2015, the planet has already seen 11 extra superhot days. However, the study reveals a stark global inequity: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face massive increases in heat exposure—up to 149 extra days annually—despite contributing only 1% of global carbon emissions. In contrast, the world’s top carbon emitters—the U.S., China, and India—account for 42% of global emissions but face only 23–30 extra superhot days. Experts warn that this growing disparity could deepen global inequality and trigger geopolitical instability.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
